bestBHT.bht: When Jesus saw the woman who had been bent over for eighteen years, he called her to come to him. By laying his hands on her, he not only released her from the power that had bound her muscles but also conferred upon her the strength to rise and stand upright. This miraculous act demonstrated both his power and his compassion, as he freed her from her long affliction and showed himself to be the Messiah.

Henry Alford: Thou art loosed, expresses the setting free of her muscles from the power which bound them down.
The laying on of the divine hands confers upon her strength to rise and stand upright.
It would be, in such a case, one thing to be loosed from the stiffening of years,—and another to have strength at once conferred to stand upright.
Albert Barnes: Thou art loosed from thine infirmity - This was a remarkable declaration.
How clear would be the proofs from such a case that he was the Messiah!
How mighty the power of him that by a word could restore her to health!
Marvin Vincent: Thou art loosed [απολελυσαι]. The only passage in the New Testament where the word is used of disease.
Medical writers use it of releasing from disease, relaxing tendons, and taking off bandages.
John Calvin: In this miracle, as well as in others, Christ exhibited a proof both of his power and of his grace...
Philip Schaff: There is no evidence, that she asked for a cure.
Her muscles were released from the influence which bound them.
This suggests (as also Luke 13:16) Satanic power, which our Lord always drove away with a word.
Archibald T. Robertson: He called her to come to him.
Thou art loosed, to stay free.
Only N.T. example of use about disease.
John Gill: And when Jesus saw her...he called her to him, to come nearer him."
Out of great compassion to her, seeing her in this miserable condition."
Christ...burst her bonds asunder, dispossessed the evil spirit, and delivered her from her long affliction.

bhtAttempts.bht: When Jesus saw the woman who had been bent over for eighteen years, he called her to come to him. By laying his hands on her, he not only released her from the power that had bound her muscles, but he also conferred upon her the strength to rise and stand upright. This was not just a case of being loosed from the stiffness of years, but a miraculous act that granted her immediate strength. The use of the word loosed in this context is unique in the New Testament and is often used in medical writings to signify the release from disease. It is evident from this miracle that Jesus displayed his power and compassion by freeing her from her affliction.

When Jesus saw the woman who had been bent over for eighteen years, he called her to come to him. By laying his hands on her, he not only released her from the power that had bound her muscles but also conferred upon her the strength to rise and stand upright. This was not just a case of being loosed from the stiffness of years but a miraculous act that granted her immediate strength. The use of the word loosed in this context is unique in the New Testament and signifies the release from disease.

When Jesus saw the woman who had been bent over for eighteen years, he called her to come to him. By laying his hands on her, he not only released her from the power that had bound her muscles but also conferred upon her the strength to rise and stand upright. This miraculous act demonstrated both his power and his compassion, as he freed her from her long affliction and showed himself to be the Messiah.

When Jesus saw the woman who had been bent over for eighteen years, he called her to come to him. By laying his hands on her, he not only released her from the power that had bound them down but also conferred upon her the strength to rise and stand upright. This act of freeing her from the stiffness of years and granting her immediate strength was unique in the New Testament, signifying the release from disease. It was a remarkable declaration and a powerful evidence of his messianic authority and compassion.
